factoid: The speaker invited Peter Kirílych to smoke.

Pierre was undecided.

Natásha's look was cordial.
Natásha's look caused Pierre to become agitated and undecided.

The Count said Pierre often does not come.
The Count said Natásha brightens up when Pierre is present.

Pierre said he has business.
Natásha began to speak resolutely and then stopped.

Pierre's smile expressed suffering.

Pierre left the room.
Pierre decided not to go to the Rostóvs' anymore.

Pétya wept bitterly.
Pétya came in to tea.
Pétya was silent.

Pétya arranged his hair.
Pétya arranged his collar.
Pétya aimed to look like a grown-up man.

Pétya gesticulated.

Pétya took his cap.
Pétya left the house by the back door.
Pétya tried to avoid notice.
Pétya decided to go to the Emperor.
Pétya intended to explain to a gentleman-in-waiting that he is Count Rostóv.

Pétya believed youth is not a hindrance to loyalty.
Pétya was ready to serve.

Pétya's youthfulness was a factor in reaching the Emperor.
Pétya thought everyone would be surprised by his youthfulness.

As Pétya approached the Kremlin, he avoided being crushed.
Pétya stuck out his elbows menacingly.
At the Trinity Gateway, Pétya was pressed to the wall.
People at the Trinity Gateway were probably unaware of his patriotic intentions.
Pétya had to give in and stop while carriages passed beneath the archway.
Beside Pétya stood a peasant woman.
Beside Pétya stood a footman.
Beside Pétya stood two tradesmen.
Beside Pétya stood a discharged soldier.

Pétya worked his way with his elbows.

The woman asked why Pétya was pushing.

The footman pushed Pétya into a filthy corner.
